Award.AwardTitle: Incorporation and Culture Change as the Result of Culture Contact

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Scott Ortman of the University of Colorado Boulder will conduct research that re-frames the effects of Spanish contact on Pueblo Indian communities. Recent studies of the initial century of Spanish contact in New Mexico have tended to focus on population decline, resistance and revitalization. The hardships brought on by Spanish colonization were real, but contemporary Pueblo tradition also incorporates ideas and practices that were introduced by Spanish settlers. This suggests a deeper understanding of the Columbian encounter can be obtained through study of this incorporation process. Dr. Ortman will conduct archaeological, ethnographic, and linguistic research in collaboration with the Pueblo of Pojoaque, a federally-recognized Indian tribe, to determine why certain elements of Spanish culture were incorporated into Pueblo tradition while others were not, to document the effects of introduced domesticates for Pueblo settlement and land-use, and to determine the extent to which Spanish introductions affected material standards of living, or what Pueblo people refer to today as "abundance." The research activities will involve contemporary Pueblo community members and University of Colorado students in all stages of the process, from field recording to exhibit design to final publications. The work will document and provide insight into a unique American way of life.

Existing documentary evidence concerning the Columbian encounter is highly biased toward the perspectives and perceptions of Spanish colonizers, and reliance on these sources has led to an imbalanced view of this period in contemporary society. This research addresses the imbalance by collecting new archaeological data from Pueblo settlements inhabited before, during, and after Spanish contact, and by analyzing words for Spanish introductions in Pueblo languages. The results will support a more realistic understanding of native experience during the Columbian encounter. The project will problematize the concepts of "native" and "tradition" in developing a view of Spanish contact that de-emphasizes historical rupture and emphasizes social processes that have governed cross-cultural interaction throughout history. It will also blur the boundary between Pre-Hispanic and Historical archaeology in New Mexico by extending the chronological scope of regional archaeological datasets, and it will provide the first comprehensive study of changes in Pueblo languages that accompanied Spanish contact.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past three years, a team of archaeologists, linguists and tribal elders have joined forced to investigate the role of incorporation in cultural change. The team focused on the manner in which elements of Spanish culture were incorporated into the traditions of Tewa Pueblo peoples of New Mexico during the initial century of contact. Studies of words for Spanish introductions in Pueblo languages found that about two-thirds of these introductions were labeled using native terms rather than loans from Spanish. This suggests successful incorporation includes a bias against marking introductions as foreign. Archaeological survey and analysis of museum collections also found differences in the speed of incorporation that reflect differences in the ways introduced elements interface with existing elements. For example, the team's research suggested that wool was incorporated into Pueblo tradition rapidly and replaced cotton as the primary textile fiber during the 17th century, but wheat was incorporated more slowly. This slower rate of incorporation for wheat is attributable to the central role of maize in Pueblo religion, which extended even to Catholic practice. Finally, compilation and analysis of archaeological data for hundreds of sites in the region determined that Tewa society experienced a centuries-long period of economic expansion starting in the 14th century that continued into the initial decades of Spanish contact. The high level of continuity in housing, production and consumption rates across this period suggests a more complex interpretation of the Spanish entrada, with some introductions being beneficial for Pueblo people even as others were quite detrimental. 

These insights were made possible by the innovative approach of the research team, which brought University of Colorado Boulder students and faculty together with native students and elders from the Pueblo of Pojoaque and other Tewa communities as co-investigators in the field and laboratory. This approach brought archaeological evidence and tradtional knowledge into dialogue on a level playing field, leading to new insights and directions for investigation. So in addition to providing new insights into the incorporation process, this project has provided an example of how achaeology can be done in partnership with native communities, and in ways that provide mutual benefits that are consistent with both scientific and native values.
